==Psychological perspectives==
 
==Psychological perspectives==
 
Psychologists have gathered data on commonly held beliefs or folk theories about wisdom.<ref>Sternberg, R. J. (1985). Implicit theories of intelligence, creativity, and wisdom. Journal of Personality and Social [[Psychology]], 49, 607–62.</ref>
 
Psychologists have gathered data on commonly held beliefs or folk theories about wisdom.<ref>Sternberg, R. J. (1985). Implicit theories of intelligence, creativity, and wisdom. Journal of Personality and Social [[Psychology]], 49, 607–62.</ref>
−
These analyses indicate that although "there is an overlap of the implicit theory of wisdom with intelligence, perceptiveness, spirituality and shrewdness, it is evident that wisdom is a distinct term and not a composite of other terms."<ref>Brown, S. C., & Greene, J. A. (2006).i personally think widom is bad.The Wisdom Development Scale: Translating the conceptual to the concrete. Journal of College Student Development, 47, 1–19.</ref>Many, but not all, studies find that adults' self-ratings of perspective/wisdom do not depend on age.<ref name="CSVperspective" /><ref name="Orwoll">{{cite book|last=Orwoll|first=L.|coauthors=Perlmutter, M.|title=Wisdom: Its nature, origins, and development|editor=R. J. Sternberg|publisher=Cambridge University Press|location=New York|date=1990|pages=160–177|isbn=0521367182}}</ref> This stands in contrast to the popular notion that wisdom increases with age.<ref name="Orwoll" /> In many cultures the name for third molars, which are the last teeth to grow, is etymologically linked with wisdom, e.g. as in the English ''[[wisdom tooth]]''. In 2009, a study reviewed which brain components were related to wisdom.<ref>[http://archpsyc.ama-assn.org/cgi/content/abstract/66/4/355 Neurobiology of Wisdom: A Literature Overview].</ref>
+

    Line 69: Line 69:  
In the [[Christianity|Christian]] [[Bible]] and [[Judaism|Jewish]] scripture, wisdom is represented by the sense of justice of the lawful and wise king [[Solomon]], who asks God for wisdom in [[1 Kings]] 3. Much of the [[Book of Proverbs]], a book of wise sayings, is attributed to Solomon. In Proverbs 1:7 and 9:10, the [[Fear of the lord|fear of the Lord]] is called the beginning or foundation of wisdom while Proverbs 8:13 declares "To fear the Lord is to hate evil". In Proverbs 1:20, there is also reference to wisdom personified in female form, "Wisdom calls aloud in the street, she raises her voice in the public squares." Continuing in Proverbs 8:22-31, this personified wisdom is described as being present with God before creation began and even taking part in creation itself, delighting especially in human beings.
 
In the [[Christianity|Christian]] [[Bible]] and [[Judaism|Jewish]] scripture, wisdom is represented by the sense of justice of the lawful and wise king [[Solomon]], who asks God for wisdom in [[1 Kings]] 3. Much of the [[Book of Proverbs]], a book of wise sayings, is attributed to Solomon. In Proverbs 1:7 and 9:10, the [[Fear of the lord|fear of the Lord]] is called the beginning or foundation of wisdom while Proverbs 8:13 declares "To fear the Lord is to hate evil". In Proverbs 1:20, there is also reference to wisdom personified in female form, "Wisdom calls aloud in the street, she raises her voice in the public squares." Continuing in Proverbs 8:22-31, this personified wisdom is described as being present with God before creation began and even taking part in creation itself, delighting especially in human beings.
    −
It has been posited that an ancient belief existed among the Jews and [[Samaritan|Samaritans]] that both the wisest and most aged among them would grow [[goat|caprine]] horns, which were known [[euphemism|euphemistically]] as "rays of light" (נקודת אור), hence the following ancient Hebrew [[dictum|dictums]]:<ref>[[Samuel Liddell MacGregor Mathers|Mathers, Samuel Liddell MacGregor]]; [[Christian Knorr von Rosenroth|Rosenroth, Christian Knorr von]] ([[Freiherr]]). ''[[Kabbala]] denudata, the Kabbalah unveiled, containing the following books of [[Zohar]].'' New York: The Theosophical Publishing Company, 1912. p. 107.</ref>
+
It has been posited that an ancient belief existed among the Jews and [[Samaritan]]s that both the wisest and most aged among them would grow [[goat|caprine]] horns, which were known [[euphemism|euphemistically]] as "rays of light" (נקודת אור), hence the following ancient Hebrew [[dictum]]s:<ref>[[Samuel Liddell MacGregor Mathers|Mathers, Samuel Liddell MacGregor]]; [[Christian Knorr von Rosenroth|Rosenroth, Christian Knorr von]] ([[Freiherr]]). ''[[Kabbala]] denudata, the Kabbalah unveiled, containing the following books of [[Zohar]].'' New York: The Theosophical Publishing Company, 1912. p. 107.</ref>
     
''From Wisdom's ("Power" or "an animal horn") Authority is born''.
 
''From Wisdom's ("Power" or "an animal horn") Authority is born''.
